Section 68.155(f): Safety Improvements:

Recommendations for safety improvements can be identified in the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), which was completed per OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119(e) on May 20, 2024.  There were no recommended improvements.  Additional recommendations may be made upon review of any accidents and/or when the PHA is updated every five years.

The Charles M. Bolton Plant facility has a documented Prevention Program for the Chlorination System that documents release prevention measures.  These prevention measures include elements such as employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training, contractors, pre-startup review, mechanical integrity, hot work permits, management of change, incident investigation, and compliance audits.  

The Chlorination Facility is equipped with many safety features to prevent public exposure in the event of a chlorine leak.  One chlorine leak detector is located in the Storage/Unloading Room and one in the Chlorine Feed Room.  To allow safety personnel time to respond to emergencies, an audible warning alarm sounds inside and outside of the building when chlorine levels reach 1.0 ppm.  At 1.0 ppm at high level alarm is sounded and the normal building ventilation system automatically shuts down to contain the chlorine.  In addition, the chlorine detector alarms are connected to the CMBP control panel, and the CMBP, and Richard Miller Water Treatment Plant SCADA system.  This alerts the staff at all plants in the event of a chlorine release. CMBP employees who are involved in chlorine operations are trained in specific procedures regarding handling and storage of chlorine at the facility. There is also a single pass chlorine scrubber which uses a dry media. The scrubber activates automatically in the event of a chlorine alarm, and must be manually shut down. The exhaust vent on the scrubber is equipped with a chlorine detector to ensure chlorine is not passed to the atmosphere. 



Section 68.155(d): Five-Year Accident History.

The Charles M. Bolton Plant has had no accidental releases of chlorine in the last five years that have resulted in on-site injuries or off-site injuries or other impacts.

otal release from one of the one-ton containers of chlorine (greatest amount held in a single vessel).  It is assumed that the container ruptures and its entire contents escape to the outside air in 10 minutes. Additionally, the worst-case scenario requires a ground level release height.  The rate of chlorine release for the worst-case scenario is 200 pounds of chlorine per minute.  Using the reference tables in the USEPA RMP Guidance for WWTPs, a toxic endpoint of 3.0 miles was determined for the worst case scenario.  The residential population within a 3.0 mile radius of influence for Charles M. Bolton Plant is determined to be approximately 25,450 people.  Also included within this radius are several schools, parks and industrial areas.

The facility is also required to complete at least one alternative release scenario.  The alternative release scenario was evaluated in accordance with the guidelines provided in 40 CFR 68.22 and 40 CFR 68.28.  The alternative release scenario selected was that of a 3/16 inch diameter opening in a valve, gasket, flexible tubing, or piping occurring inside the enclosed Storage/Unloading Room or Chlorine Feed Room.  .  Using the guidance for alternative release scenarios of chlorine USEPA RMP Comp and without taking passive mitigation of the building into consideration, this chlorine gas release would result in a release rate of 3.0 pounds of chlorine per minute for a period of 30 minutes, resulting in a 90 pound gas release from the building. The reference tables in USEPA RMP Comp give a distance of less than 0.1 miles to the toxic endpoint for the alternative scenario. The residential population within a 0.1 mile radius of influence of the CMBP Chlorination System is determined to be approximately zero persons.  The radius of influence does go offsite and includes the East River Road, however, it does not encompass any residences, schools, hospitals, parks, or prisons.

Section 68.155(a): Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies.

The Charles M. Bolton Plant (CMBP) has emergency response procedures in place, as documented in the facilitys Emergency Action Plan.  This plan has been documented by the City staff responsible for the operation and maintenance of the CMBP.  The CMBP has procedures in place, including both onsite activities and coordination with offsite responders that must be followed in the event of a chlorine leak.  All personnel involved in handling chlorine are trained with regard to chlorine safety and accident prevention.


Section 68.155(b): Stationary Source and Substance Handled.

The stationary source subject to 40 CFR Part 68 is the Charles M. Bolton Plant (CMBP) Chlorination System.  The CMBP has a design capacity of 40 million gallons of water per day (MGD) and treats groundwater to drinking water standards.  The CMBP Chlorination System is located in the Administration and Filtration Building, and is divided into two rooms dedicated to specific tasks: the Storage/Unloading Room, and the Chlorine Feed Room.

The Storage/Unloading Room houses a maximum of ten (10) one-ton containers that store chlorine as a pressurized liquid.  For normal operating conditions, there are four one-ton containers of chlorine connected to the header A system.  There is also three one-ton container connected to a second manifold B for use if the main header system is inoperable.  The remaining three
 one-ton containers are stored in the room for use when the on-line containers are exhausted.  Chlorine gas is fed from the containers through pressure regulators to the chlorinators in the Chlorine Feed Room.  Three vacuum chlorinators and five water-operated injectors are provided for solution chlorine feed at various process locations.

Introduction

USEPAs Risk Management Program (RMP) Rule (40 CFR 68), published in the Federal Register on June 20, 1996, was developed to assist facilities in preventing accidental releases of highly toxic or flammable chemicals.  The RMP applies to an owner or operator of a stationary source that has more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance in a process, as determined under Section 68.115.

The USEPA has established three tiers of requirements to reduce the level of effort for facilities with a lower risk of offsite impacts.  These tiers are known as Programs 1, 2, and 3.  Program 1 applies to any process that has not had an accidental release with prescribed offsite consequences for five years and has no public receptors impacted by a worst-case release.  Program 3 applies to processes in specified industries, and to all processes subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard, unless the process is eligible for Program 1.  Program 2 applies to processes not covered by Programs 1 or 3.

The Greater Cincinnati Water Works, Charles M. Bolton Plant (CMBP) utilizes more than a threshold quantity of chlorine (2,500 pounds) in their process.  Therefore, this facility is required to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP) as defined in Section 68.150. The initial submittal was filed in June 1999. The next required submittal will be in June 2029. Public employees are covered under the State of Ohios Public Employee Risk Reduction Program (PERRP), which has adopted by reference the requirements of OSHAs (PSM) Standard.  Based on the March 1999 revised USEPA RMP Guidance for Wastewater Treatment Plants (WWTPs) (EPA 550-B-98-010), the Charles M. Bolton Plant is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard and the worst case release scenario impacts public receptors.  Therefore, the Charles M. Bolton Plant Chlorination Facility is subject to the Program 3 requirements of the RMP Regulation.
